The Garden is about as good as it gets for

3.text: for a commencement. All you have to do is just

6.text:
look up there at the banners heralding the

15.text:
I know some of you come
from somewhere else, but you’re here. (Laughter.)

20.text:
The 17th Celtics championship banner thanks
to the second coming of the “Big Three.”

28.text:
(Applause.) And with my chauvinism of 28 years
representing the state in the Senate, I’ll

34.text:
tell you this is a living reminder that Boston is
the number-one sports town anywhere. (Applause.)

44.text:
Now, at the moment, for the Red Sox “anywhere”
just happens to be first place, while the

53.text:
Yankees are in last. (Applause.) So don’t
let anyone tell you that our country is not

69.text:
Now, graduating class, I got to tell you,
you really do look spectacular. I want you

75.text:
to – I mean, just look around you. Classmates
of every race, religion, gender, shape, size

84.text:
– 85 countries represented and dozens of
languages spoken. You are the most diverse

92.text:
class in Northeastern’s history – in other
words, you are Donald Trump’s worst nightmare.

118.text:
Now, you may not know it, but there
is at least one thing that truly unites you:

123.text:
You’re all going to be in really big
trouble if you forget that

130.text:
Now, to the parents who are here – moms
and dads – if you feel anything like I did

136.text:
when my daughters graduated, your emotions
have to be mixed – a little bit sad, a little

143.text:
bit relieved – (laughter) – incredibly
proud, and absolutely blown away by how short

150.text:
the interval is between diapers and diplomas.
(Laughter.)

155.text:
Now, speaking of blown away, I want to congratulate
you guys for just getting here in time for

163.text:
this ceremony. (Laughter.) I’m told you
had to report at 8:00 a.m.

171.text:
SECRETARY KERRY: Well – (laughter) – I
mean, I got to tell you, that’s either crazy

176.text:
early or crazy late depending on whether you
actually went to bed. (Laughter.) But why

182.text:
would the last night be different from the
rest of your college career, right?

186.text:
Now, I’ve given a few commencement speeches
before, and the biggest challenge is always

193.text:
to follow everything that’s come before
you, particularly the student speakers. And

197.text:
I want to thank Annika and Ben, and I want
to thank (inaudible) and Distilled Harmony

205.text:
for making my job a lot tougher today. (Applause.)
Thank you.

210.text:
I really want you to know that I accept this
honor with great humility, and particularly

218.text:
because Northeastern was kind enough to bestow
an honorary degree on my daughter Vanessa

224.text:
last year, who was involved in a global health
program which you recognized. I come here

230.text:
absolutely promising not to sugarcoat reality
because that is the last thing that you need.

238.text:
No one here needs to be told that life can
be a struggle, whether it’s over grades

244.text:
or affording tuition or something more complicated
– friends, family, illness, or the death

251.text:
of a loved one. No words of mine can change
those realities, and no lecture can lessen

260.text:
And as we were reminded earlier, you are still
mourning the tragic loss of Victoria McGrath

268.text:
and Priscilla Perez Torres. Even before, on
Patriot’s Day 2013, when Victoria was among

277.text:
those hurt by a terrorist’s bomb, this community
felt the weight of a wounded world. So this

287.text:
morning, we grieve and we celebrate all at
the same time. And in a way, there is no better

296.text:
shorthand description of life itself. And
no better two-word summary of this gathering,

302.text:
I think, today than, “Northeastern strong,
Huskies strong.”

309.text:
Now, I have learned – (applause) – I have
learned that resilience is really just the

319.text:
beginning of what Northeastern is all about.
Service is at the heart of this institution.

327.text:
So it’s no surprise that Northeastern’s
effort to keep faith with those who keep America

333.text:
safe is actually unparalleled. We can be proud
that Northeastern graduates veterans at a

340.text:
rate 30 percent above the national average.
(Applause.) And to soldiers, sailors, airmen

353.text:
and Marines, from one veteran to so many others,
I am proud to say that the class of 2016 is

359.text:
the rule, not the exception. Thank you, Northeastern,
and thanks to all of you who have worn or

376.text:
Now, I am honored this morning to address
a university family that thankfully is unafraid,

386.text:
utterly unafraid to look beyond our borders
and into the future. And it’s also almost

393.text:
cliche to say that you have global vision,
but Northeastern really does, and it’s different.

401.text:
President Aoun tests the limits – your bold
commitment to experiential learning, your

407.text:
leadership on the environment, the opportunities
for international study, a new campus in Silicon

413.text:
Valley, and cutting-edge research in things
like high-rate nano-manufacturing. And class

421.text:
of 2016, believe me, if you are mastering
a technology that your parents can’t even

427.text:
pronounce, you are doing something right.
(Laughter and applause.)

431.text:
And just think, after today you’re going
to have a leg up on Facebook’s Mark Zuckerberg.

438.text:
You’ll actually have a college degree. (Laughter.)
In fact, Northeastern’s example should speak

446.text:
to every one of us about the massive transformation
that is taking place around the world. Northeastern’s

454.text:
gone global. Our leading corporations are
going global. Health and medicine and film

461.text:
are going global. And you don’t have to
be great at math to understand that our economy

466.text:
can’t grow if we don’t sell things to
the 95 percent of the world’s customers

472.text:
who live in other countries. You don’t have
to be a doctor to understand that we can’t

478.text:
be healthy if we can’t fight things like
Ebola and Zika that may originate overseas

483.text:
but makes us just as sick as the people they
first hurt far, far from our shores. And many

490.text:
of you were in elementary school when you
learned the toughest lesson of all on 9/11.

495.text:
There are no walls big enough to stop people
from anywhere, tens of thousand miles away,

502.text:
who are determined to take their own lives
while they target others. Not in a clash of

508.text:
civilizations, but in an assault, a raw assault
on civilization itself.

516.text:
So I think that everything that we’ve lived
and learned tells us that we will never come

520.text:
out on top if we accept advice from soundbite
salesmen and carnival barkers who pretend

528.text:
the most powerful country on Earth can remain
great by looking inward and hiding behind

534.text:
walls at a time that technology has made that
impossible to do and unwise to even attempt.

541.text:
The future demands from us – (applause)
– the future demands from us something more

557.text:
than a nostalgia for some rose-tinted version
of a past that did not really exist in any

563.text:
case. And I think that everyone here, especially
the class of 2016, understands that viscerally,

571.text:
internally, intellectually. You’re about
to graduate into a complex and borderless

577.text:
world. You heard President Aoun talk in his
description about the view from space. You’re

583.text:
about to embark on careers that will take
many of you to companies not yet founded,

590.text:
using devices not yet developed, based on
ideas not yet conceived. That is how fast

598.text:
things are moving. And that doesn’t mean
you have to succumb to science fiction; you’re

604.text:
not going to all be replaced by robots, because
the economy of tomorrow will have enormous

609.text:
space for those with the energy, the training,
and the courage to compete.

614.text:
And Northeastern has made sure that you have
that and more, because this university is

620.text:
blessed with a global vision and so are you
its graduates now. Believe me, that is critical,

629.text:
because you’re entering a world where thinking
globally is absolutely essential to seizing

633.text:
opportunities and confronting the challenges
that we face.

638.text:
When I was younger, we had more than our share
of national traumas, including a long and

645.text:
bloody war in Southeast Asia. But it was also
a time when the dividing line between ideologies

653.text:
was simpler, when the primary forces shaping
our world were governments of recognized states.

662.text:
Today, we face a world that is much more complicated,
less hierarchical, where non-state actors

671.text:
play a central role; where disturbing images
and outright lies can circle the globe in

677.text:
an instant; where dangers like climate change,
terrorism, and disease do not respect borders

684.text:
or any of the norms of behavior; and where
tribal and sectarian hatreds are as prominent

690.text:
as they have been in centuries. Now, for some
people, that is all they need simply to climb

697.text:
under the sheets, close their eyes, and wish
the world away. And shockingly, we even see

703.text:
this attitude from some who think they ought
to be entrusted with the job of managing international

710.text:
It seems obvious that understanding to – the
need to engage with the greater world, with

716.text:
the wider world should be a threshold requirement
for those in high office. And yet the specter

723.text:
of isolationism once again hovers over our
nation. I thought we had learned the lessons

730.text:
from the 20th century when an isolationist
foreign policy and a protectionist tariff

736.text:
policy contributed to two global wars and
the Great Depression.

742.text:
Well, the desire to turn inward and to shut
out the world may be especially seductive

748.text:
in an era as complicated as this. But it is
not a responsible choice for the most prosperous

755.text:
and powerful nation on the planet – which
happens to also be the leader of the free

765.text:
Now, as Secretary of State, let me assure
you: when you consider the range of challenges

775.text:
that the world is struggling with, most countries
don’t lie awake at night worrying about

782.text:
America’s presence; they worry about what
would happen in our absence.

787.text:
So we cannot be seduced. For us, the lessons
of history are clear.

793.text:
We don’t see an excuse for inaction. We
see a mandate to lead. Because the greatest

800.text:
challenges that our world confronts are best
addressed – and in some cases can only be

806.text:
addressed – by good and capable people working
in common cause with citizens of other nations.

814.text:
You often hear politicians talking about American
exceptionalism, and indeed, this nation is

821.text:
exceptional. But remember, please, we’re
not exceptional because we say we are and

828.text:
keep repeating it; we’re exceptional because
we do exceptional things.

834.text:
In other words, greatness isn’t about bragging.
It’s about doing. It’s about never being

839.text:
satisfied. It’s about testing the limits
of what we can achieve together – of what

845.text:
America and its partners can accomplish in
the world. And that is exactly what we are

851.text:
trying to do with the United States already
now, today, more deeply engaged on more important

858.text:
issues, in more parts of the globe, than ever
before in our history. And we are profoundly

865.text:
conscious of the gravity of the challenges.
In the words of the Haitian proverb, there

876.text:
One of those mountains is the effort to safeguard
future generations from the harmful effects

881.text:
of climate change. I am proud to say that
the United States is leading the way together

888.text:
with many other nations, and last month, with
my granddaughter on my lap, I formally committed

893.text:
the United States to set an example for the
196 nations that have pledged to curb greenhouse

900.text:
gas emissions and make progress towards a
low carbon energy future. (Applause.)

912.text:
I want you to think about that, because with
just a few exceptions – including, I am

917.text:
sad to say, an embarrassing coterie of naysayers
and science-deniers here in the United States

923.text:
– the whole world has now, in Paris and
in New York, for the first time accepted the

931.text:
need for a revolution in how we produce and
use energy.

935.text:
Ladies and gentlemen, last March was the hottest
March in recorded history; last year, the

943.text:
hottest year in recorded history; the last
10 years, the hottest decade in recorded history;

949.text:
the one before that, the third hottest. The
facts are simply staggering. And yet, despite

959.text:
all the science, one of my former colleagues
thought it would be persuasive to walk onto

964.text:
the floor of the Senate with a snowball in
his hand and point to it as evidence that

968.text:
climate change is a hoax. Well, I hate to
tell him it proves something, that’s for

975.text: sure, but not what he intended. (Applause.)

985.text:
At the same time, just in the past four years,
a record $230 billion was spent in the United

993.text:
States of America in response to extreme weather
events. Just the other day in Houston they

1001.text:
had 17 inches of rain in 24 hours. That is
the entire amount of rain – more than – than

1007.text:
they had last year in the entire summer. But
just imagine if we had put even a small fraction

1014.text:
of that 230 billion into efforts to prevent
or at least prepare for the worst impacts

1021.text:
And there’s one more thing to remember.
Don’t believe the doubters who claim that

1026.text:
we have to make a choice between protecting
the environment or growing the economy. That’s

1030.text:
a lie. There are millions of jobs to be created,
businesses to be built, fortunes to be made

1037.text:
in tapping the potential of renewable energy,
and I hope that many of you will share in

1049.text:
In Paris last December, we took an unprecedented
step with our first ever international agreement

1058.text:
to combat climate change. It is literally,
though – I mean, it isn’t the solution

1065.text:
in itself because it’s not going to guarantee
we hold the Earth’s temperature to a warning

1069.text:
of 2 degrees centigrade. But what it does
is it sends a massive signal to the marketplace

1075.text:
for private entrepreneurs, for scientists,
for creative minds to go to work to find the

1082.text:
alternative, for the next Elon Musk, for the
next Steve Jobs, whoever it is that’s going

1086.text:
to produce the battery storage or the ability
for us to solve this problem. Paris is the

1092.text:
beginning of what we have to do to meet this
challenge.

1096.text:
And in the years ahead, we will need an all-out
global commitment to clean air, clean harbors,

1102.text:
clean coasts, renewable energy, and the preservation
of our endangered ocean and marine resources.

1108.text:
And I say to you today with certainty, this
is one of the great challenges of our time.

1116.text:
And hand-in-hand with this challenge is another
mountain to scale – the effort to eliminate

1122.text:
poverty from the world. Now, your instant
reaction may be to say wow, that’s just

1128.text:
too big, that’s not possible. But the truth
is it’s not only possible, we’re making

1134.text:
enormous progress in trying to achieve it
right now.

1137.text:
Today, extreme poverty worldwide has fallen
below 10 percent for the first time in history.

1144.text:
The revolution that is taking place on a global
basis has brought hundreds of millions of

1148.text:
people in India, hundreds of millions of people
in China into the middle class. And while

1154.text:
that’s welcome news, we’re not satisfied
because 700 million people still have to survive

1159.text:
on less than what it costs for us to grab
a couple of Dunkin Donuts a day, because the

1166.text:
gap – the gap that was referred to earlier
between rich and poor – remains far too

1174.text:
So at the UN last fall, the world came together
and agreed to move forward on an agenda that

1180.text:
not only will reduce poverty further but will
ensure that every boy and girl can attend

1186.text:
school, that every mother gets the health
care that needs to survive, and that every

1192.text:
available resource is used to win the fight
against epidemic diseases. After all, my friends,

1199.text:
we defied predictions by stopping Ebola. Remember?
Experts said that a million people would be

1206.text:
dead by Christmas of 2014 without action.
Well, we took action. President Obama had

1213.text:
the foresight to send 3,000 troops to West
Africa to build capacity, to provide care

1219.text:
and aid, and to stem the spread of the epidemic.
And now, thanks to unprecedented global response

1225.text:
– global response, not one country, not
turning inwards and avoiding responsibility

1230.text:
but accepting responsibility – today the
most affected countries are virtually Ebola-free.

1238.text:
There is absolutely no reason – (applause)
– there is absolutely no reason to believe

1248.text:
that we can’t do the same for malaria and
the same for the Zika virus. Right now, if

1254.text:
we uphold and continue our commitments to
critical global health programs in Africa,

1261.text:
we can see the birth of the first AIDS-free
generation – an extraordinary accomplishment.

1272.text:
And yet another mountain that we have to climb,
which stands in the way of the calm that we

1282.text:
want in our lives and the stability that we
need to achieve many of the things we want

1286.text:
to achieve, is the scourge of violent extremism
that threatens communities around the world.

1293.text:
And there can be no peace without eliminating
this scourge.

1298.text:
I mentioned Victoria McGrath earlier, who
was injured in the Boston Marathon attack.

1304.text:
So Boston and Northeastern need no lessons
in how important it is to win the battle against

1311.text:
terrorists. I want you to know, without exaggeration,
we will win it and we are even winning it

1320.text:
now. In Syria and Iraq, we have degraded the
leadership of the terrorist group known as

1325.text:
ISIL or Daesh, and we and our partners have
liberated a third of the land that it once

1330.text:
occupied, and we are continuing to move. They
have not taken one piece of territory and

1335.text:
held it since May of last year, but we’re
not going to be successful in the long run

1341.text:
– (applause) – we’re not going to be
successful in the long run if the world continues

1347.text:
to turn away from other kinds of problems
and allows the production of terrorists at

1352.text:
such an alarming rate. And that is why it
is critical that we expand our commitment

1357.text: to taking on violent extremism at the roots.

1361.text:
We know that there are millions of young people
across the globe with no jobs, no opportunity,

1368.text:
but they have smartphones in their hands.
They can see what the rest of the world has.

1373.text:
And in the seeing of that, they also see and
know what they don’t have. I want you to

1380.text:
know that the fruit vendor who ignited the
Arab Spring in Tunisia – he wasn’t religiously

1391.text:
motivated. There was no religion at all in
what he did. He was tired of being slapped

1395.text:
around by a corrupt policeman who wanted a
bribe, and he was so frustrated by his inability

1401.text:
to sell his own fruit where he wanted that
he self-immolated. And that ignited a revolution

1408.text:
that saw a dictator of 30 years driven out
of the country. That’s what ignited Tahrir

1412.text:
Square. There was no religion in Tahrir Square
in terms of what motivated it. It was young

1418.text:
people like you who wanted an opportunity
like you have here, but they wanted it in

1423.text:
their home and for their country. We need
these young people to know that their countries

1428.text:
and their communities will not be abandoned
to the clutches of terrorists and extremists.

1434.text:
Experts tell us that a 50 percent reduction
in youth unemployment could lift the global

1440.text:
living standards by 6 percent or more. So
our mission – your mission – is to create

1446.text:
jobs not just in a few places but in many
places. And that’s going to require the

1451.text:
deep involvement jointly of the private sector,
civil society, academic institutions, international

1458.text:
organizations, and governments everywhere,
and still there will be no guarantees. And

1465.text:
let me make it clear: Doing this is not about
charity. It’s not about giving something

1472.text:
for nothing. It’s about building our own
security and preventing the conflicts of the

1477.text:
future that may inevitably see us having to
become involved.

1482.text:
There used to be a famous song during World
War I, “Over There,” sang about the distant

1491.text:
shores where our soldiers traveled to fight.
But in our time, in your time, there is no

1498.text:
“over there;” in a digital, well-traveled
world – in a global marketplace – those

1503.text:
distant shores are practically always right
at our doorstep.

1508.text:
So all of us need to do much more to build
relationships with partners overseas, to deliver

1514.text:
assistance to families and communities abroad,
to promote stability worldwide. And we need

1519.text:
to do this not because it is morally right,
which it is; not just because it’s in keeping

1525.text:
with our national ethos, which is also true;
but because our own security and prosperity

1533.text:
My friends, we are blessed to live in a country
with a $17 trillion economy, and yet we spend

1541.text:
just one penny on every dollar of our federal
budget on all of our foreign aid.

1548.text:
The fact is there is much more that we can
do and must do to encourage and reward innovation,

1555.text:
to diversify economies, to improve governance,
to stop corruption, to ensure the education

1562.text:
of young people and that it actually teaches
young people what they need to know and keeps

1570.text:
Now, there is much more that we can invest
and many more projects for my generation and

1577.text:
yours to take on as you take on your careers
in the days ahead.

1582.text:
Now, I ask you just for a moment to think
about the careers of the three distinguished

1587.text:
Americans who preceded me in receiving honorary
degrees from this university today. Over a

1594.text:
period of decades, Susan Hockfield dedicated
her vision and her talent to the fight against

1601.text:
brain cancer. Through a combination of genius
and high purpose, Tom McCarthy has reached

1607.text:
the pinnacle of his art, the storytelling.
Charlie Bolden has been an aviator, an astronaut,

1614.text:
a military commander, the administrator of
NASA, and above all, an inspiring leader of

1621.text:
None of them would be here today if they were
easily satisfied – and the accomplishments,

1627.text:
which earned their degrees, came about because
they dared to always explore the outermost

1633.text: limits of what they could do.

1637.text:
Thinking especially of Charlie, and my own
Dad – who flew in the Army Air Corps in

1642.text:
the year prior to Pearl Harbor – I want
to tell you in closing about a group of people

1648.text:
who called – who were called on years ago
to test themselves under the most extreme

1656.text:
The setting was Asia; the time a few months
after the start of World War II. Enemy planes

1664.text:
dominated the traditional air routes. So to
get supplies from India to friendly forces

1670.text:
in China, American aviators had to fly hundreds
of miles over some of the world’s highest

1675.text:
mountains, including the towering Himalayas.
They called it “flying the hump,” and

1681.text: nothing similar had ever been attempted.

1683.text:
The airplanes they flew came straight from
the factory and were untested. The pilots

1689.text:
were given no charts, so they drew their own.
They were asked to fly higher than any aviator

1695.text:
had flown; higher than they had been trained
to fly; and they did so over the globe’s

1701.text:
most forbidding terrain. Amid clouds or in
darkness, a hidden peak or a crag could appear

1707.text:
at any moment and bring them down. And yet,
each night, plane after plane flew off into

1714.text:
the unknown because, had they not, allied
forces would have stood no chance.

1722.text:
Eventually, the Pentagon sent an officer to
observe and talk to the pilots, deciding in

1728.text:
each case whether the strain had become too
much and the aviator should be sent home.

1733.text:
Now, the officer reported back that some of
the flyers were mentally drained after the

1738.text:
first trip; others began to crack in a couple
of weeks or months. Only a few were able to

1745.text:
go on and on, much longer than their buddies.
In four years, more than a thousand pilots

1752.text:
were lost, but together, these courageous
airmen – none of them famous or with big

1757.text:
reputations – they kept the supply lines
open and they helped to win the war.

1764.text:
Now, some of these pilots were better able
than others to persevere, but here’s the

1769.text:
point: none failed, because all went as far
as their own capabilities allowed; each pushed

1778.text:
– like a dedicated marathoner has to push
– to plumb those final reserves of strength

1784.text: and find the spark of greatness within them.

1788.text:
That is the most that anyone could have asked
of them. It’s what history demands from

1792.text:
the United States of America. And it’s what
the future asks of you.

1798.text:
You graduate today with an increasing reservoir
of knowledge and skills – but how you use

1805.text:
those gifts, how far you push yourselves,
whether you give your own capabilities a full

1811.text:
chance – that’s not just about education;
that’s a question of character, and a question

1822.text:
When Robert Kennedy was running for president
in 1968, he raised with students at the University

1828.text:
of Kansas some basic questions about dignity
and purpose.

1833.text:
He pointed out that what we now call our GDP
was measured, among other things, in items

1840.text:
like the size of our military, the capacity
of our jails, the production of our weapons,

1846.text:
and the pollution emanating from our factories.
It was not, he lamented, measured in the things

1854.text: that mattered most in our daily lives.

1857.text:
Kennedy said, “The gross national product
does not allow for the health of our children,

1863.text:
the quality of their education or the joy
of their play. It does not include the beauty

1868.text:
of our poetry or the strength of our marriages,
the intelligence of our public debate or the

1874.text:
integrity of our public officials. It measures
neither our wit nor our courage, neither our

1881.text:
wisdom or our learning, neither our compassion
nor our devotion to country; it measures everything,

1888.text: in short, except that which makes life worthwhile.”

1893.text:
My friends, we are under no illusions about
the gigantic challenges before us. But we

1898.text:
should remember that, compared to any earlier
generation, we have tremendous advantages.

1903.text:
A child today is more likely than ever before
to be born healthy, more likely to be adequately

1909.text:
fed, more likely to get the necessary vaccinations,
more likely to attend school, more likely

1917.text:
Individuals and companies around the world
thrive on new technologies that have made

1922.text:
possible incredible breakthroughs in communications,
education, health care, economic growth. And

1929.text:
the number of democracies has doubled while
the number of nuclear weapons has fallen by

1935.text: two-thirds in just the last 30 years.

1938.text:
And all of this isn’t because of any one
country or because of what governments do

1944.text:
alone. It’s what happens when people have
faith in their own values, in their own skills;

1953.text:
when they respect the rights and dignity of
each other; and when they believe in the possibility

1958.text:
of progress no matter how many setbacks may
stand in their way.

1963.text:
That is not a complicated formula. But it
gives me a powerful sense of confidence in

1970.text:
what together we can achieve now and in what
you can achieve in the years and the decades

1976.text:
ahead. Because meeting those challenges, pursuing
arenas that excite your passions, completing

1983.text:
the mission to teach and serve and heal and
give back – that is what makes life worthwhile.

1991.text:
And I encourage you to search for the greatness
within while you push for the outermost horizons.

1999.text:
And remember always as you do this what Nelson
Mandela said: “All the hardest jobs seem

2011.text:
Congratulations again to all of you, and thank
you for letting me share this day with you.
